awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: Human-Computer Graph Exploration and Tele-Discovery
awd_abstract_narration:
The amount of information available to individuals today is enormous and rapidly increasing. People are constantly making sense of the world: scientists learning the literature in an unfamiliar field; analysts spotting abnormal activities in computer networks; and patients understanding their symptoms. From a user's perspective, the main issue is not about storage, or computing power, or large scale data processing. It is more about how to best amplify his or her limited cognition power to make sense of a large data corpus via "natural" interactive exploration. This project will undertake the challenge of computer-human interactive exploration of information-rich billion-scale network datasets. These include online social networks (who is connected to whom), online auctions (who is buying what), and intelligence analysis of communication patterns and network traffic. It will blend computer-human interaction principles and decomposable visualizations with new scalable exploration techniques that are driven by information-theoretic measures. Specifically, it will design and develop a prototype system, in which users will gradually build up an understanding of billion-scale network datasets. This research could fundamentally change how people make sense of data in many domains like scientific literature, cybersecurity, and consumer decision making. The findings could increase education effectiveness, rate of scientific discovery, and enable more literate, knowledgeable, and intelligent citizens.

This project will combine multiple novel ideas synergistically, organized into four inter-related research thrusts: (1) Adaptive Local Exploration using Minimum Description Length principles (MDL), KL divergence and Combinatorial Discrepancy. (2) Pattern Tele-Discovery & Global Summarization via algorithmic teleportation tools. These will include mechanisms for querying, discovering, linking, and visualizing multi-attributed time-evolving network patterns. (3) Scalable Data Models & Algorithms to support the interactivity demands of the previous thrusts. The proposed tools will address storage layouts via Egonet Edge Partitions and distributed sparse and persistent multidimensional sorted maps. (4) The researchers will continually conduct multi-stage evaluations in key domains, working with users throughout the entire development process. These will include iterative interface development via in-person user studies, virtual lab studies, and longitudinal field trials. For further information see the project web site at:
http://poloclub.gatech.edu/human-computer-telediscovery/
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project undertakes the challenge of computer-human interactive exploration of information-rich billion-scale network datasets. A concrete goal is to design and develop a prototype system, in which users can gradually build up an understanding of billion-scale network datasets. Refer to the public project web site: https://graphcities.cs.rutgers.edu/  It contains a variety of videos illustrating typical user explorations. A short video sample is at: https://rutgers.box.com/s/w6goff66f8zl9u5hgo3u3qmbra3yh7ro

Our major activities can be categorized in three key areas:

Area I. Massive Data Algorithms

We developed several primitives for massive network exploration. They include "Graph Cities", "Graph Waves" and "Graph Fragments". They are used to provide interactive visual exploration for billion-scale networks. A sample image is Fig. 1.

 

Graph Cities are the 3-D visual representations of partitions of a network edge set into special smaller networks, each of which is called a fixed point of degree peeling. Each fixed point of degree peeling can be decomposed into an ordered sequence of graph waves, and each graph wave can be further decomposed into an ordered sequence of graph fragments satisfying local degree conditions. Each such fixed point of degree peeling is visually represented as a Building derived from intervals of graph waves. A bucketization according to the size of fixed points of degree peeling represented by the buildings generates a 2-D position for each bucket. A special triangulation of the bucket building locations determines the street network. Refer to Fig. 2.

To explore the internal structure of a building, a user can zoom in to obtain a 3-D force-directed layout of a building's meta DAG that encodes the building's local topological structure. Each meta node is a locally connected tiny network that can be opened up and visualized with a usual node-link representation. Refer to Fig. 3, 4, and 5. 

We illustrate this novel metaphor for visual "large" network exploration with a variety of data sets that include Friendster social networks (1.8 billion edges), a co-occurrence keywords network derived from the Internet Movie Database (115 million edges), and a patent citation network (16.5 million edges). Up to 2 billion edges, all the elements of their corresponding Graph Cities are built in a few minutes (excluding disk reading and writing time). A goal of this research is to provide tools to obtain humanly-interpretable hierarchical descriptions of any network that are accessible via a Unified Web Interface for network analytics, without being constrained by the network size. A Github repository containing our current decomposition and visualization platform is at Github: https://github.com/endlesstory0428/Graph-Cities

Area II. Applications to the study of Cultural Collections

Our Massive Data Algorithms are being used by "curious" humanities researchers to build their descriptions of collections of Danish and Dutch stories and Icelandic Sagas. The methodology is based on time-weighted linking of "cultural artifacts" to "Historical Hypothesis". Users can add their own discovered "artifacts" during data explorations and have available mechanisms to add supporting evidence that may increase or decrease the "value" of the affected "Historical Hypothesis". These processes generate a network topology with their own "Graph Waves". The corresponding "Cultural Waves" have associated statistical markers that can be used as "Folktale Fingerprints" for the collection. A sample image of a summary view of a Danish Fabula pattern detected by our algorithms is Fig. 6.  

Area III. Online Instruction on Massive Data Set Exploration

This has been an unexpected benefit of our work that was otherwise adversely affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

Some of the techniques we use to drive computer-human exploration of large data sets are applicable to the problem of "Online Instruction Materials". We have been able to incorporate some of these principles into translators that take in "Tagged Textual Inputs" and transform them into "Online Presentations". Our findings are that these coordinated canvas views provide easy interfaces suitable for a variety of presentation modes. When these presentation modes are properly combined with basic conversational systems they can be used to entice viewers engagement. A sample teaching Module is at https://rutgers.box.com/s/bw32ibnfpgrlg0u9dw37denc9ez2tv0e

 

In summary, we focus on the development of generic interactive network exploration tools that combine novel visualization techniques with behind the scene scalable algorithms. So far, our research these years has resulted in 10 academic publications and four publically available software platforms ("Graph Cities", "Atlas", "FP Viewer", and "Graph Strata") . We have contributed to the dissertation work of 5 PhD students, 8 MS students, 4 undergraduate junior projects, and 5 DIMACS Research Experience for Undergraduate projects.


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: James Abello

Images (1 of )
  • A 1.8 billion edge Graph City where each vertex is a website user, and each edge represents a friendship between users.
    J. Abello, H. Zhang, D. Nakhimovich, C. Han, M. Aanjaneya
    Public Domain
    James Abello
    Fig.1 A Graph City representation of a Friendster social network
  • A 1.6 billion edge Graph City where each vertex is an academic publication, and each edge represents a citation between publications.
    J. Abello, H. Zhang, D. Nakhimovich, C. Han, M. Aanjaneya
    Public Domain
    James Abello
    Fig.2 A Graph City representation of the Microsoft academic paper citation network
  • A macro topological structure of a connected fixed point (Building, shown in top-left) in a Graph City where each vertex is a product selling on Amazon, and each edge represents two products that are co-purchased in at least one transaction.
    J. Abello, H. Zhang, D. Nakhimovich, C. Han, M. Aanjaneya
    Public Domain
    James Abello
    Fig.3 A Graph City Building internal structure of an Amazon product co-purchase network with 61 million edges
  • A node-link representation of a meta node (right) inside a Building macro topological structure (left) in a Graph City where each vertex is a biological protein, and each edge represents two proteins that have either chemical interaction or similar structure.
    J. Abello, H. Zhang, D. Nakhimovich, C. Han, M. Aanjaneya
    Public Domain
    James Abello
    Fig.4 A meta node internal structure within a Graph City building representation of a biological protein association network. This network contains 39 million edges.
  • A node-link representation (top-right) of a Building (top-left), and the labels of its nodes (bottom). This picture comes from a Graph City where each vertex is either a movie title or a movie tag, and each edge represents either a movie containing a tag, or two movies sharing at least one tag.
    J. Abello, H. Zhang, D. Nakhimovich, C. Han, M. Aanjaneya
    Public Domain
    James Abello
    Fig.5 Labels inside a Building in a Graph City representation of the IMDb movie-tag association network with 5 million edges.
  • A macro topological structure of a connected fixed point (Building, shown in top-left) in a Graph City where each vertex is either a character name, a place name, a story id, motif or topic , where each edge represents a story containing both vertices.
    J. Abello, H. Zhang, D. Nakhimovich, C. Han, M. Aanjaneya
    Public Domain
    James Abello
    Fig.6 A macro structure of a Building in a Graph City representation of a Danish Fabula network
